Main Screen (Administrator's View) &dash-main-screen;
If you are logged in as an administrator, the main screen shows the following tabs on the left navigation bar: Project and Admin.
Main Screen—Project Tab
The Project tab shows details for the projects that the user who is logged in belongs to.
&dash-project-tab;
Main Screen—Admin Tab
&cloud; ‐—Admin Tab
On this tab, you can access the following categories that belong to the System Panel:
Overview
Shows basic reports.
Instances
Lists all currently running instances belonging to various users and projects. (Not all projects may be visible to the administrator, though.)
Volumes
Lists all volumes belonging to various users and projects. (Not all projects may be visible to the administrator, though.) From here, administrators can also create volume types, according to the capabilities of the storage back-end drivers to be used.
Flavors
Lists the available sizes of the VMs that users may launch. From here, administrators can modify existing flavors or create new flavors.
Images
Shows the public images that have been uploaded or custom images of any projects that have been made visible to the administrator. Lets the administrator add images, edit image properties or delete images, if needed.
Projects
Lists the available projects. From here, administrators can create new projects, assign users to the projects, view the usage, or modify the quota settings for a project.
Users
Gives an overview of all users and lets administrators add, modify, delete or disable user accounts.
Networks
Lets you create networks and define options such as Admin State, Shared, or External Network. taroth 2013-08-02: DEVs, I'm still not sure what the difference is between this network setup and the network setup that can be done as user, please provide some input
Routers
Shows the routers that have been created. taroth 2013-08-02: DEVs, it is still unclear to me why admins can only delete routers and not create them as opposed to users?
System Info
Lists the defined Services, and the Default Quotas (hard-coded in &ostack; ∁). Includes parameters such as the number of CPUs, RAM, or instances.

chapter.sect1:
Managing Projects and Users
&projects;
As a &cloud; administrator, you can create additional projects and user accounts as needed. The following procedures guide you through the main management tasks like adding, modifying, or deleting projects and user accounts. Learn how to assign users to one or multiple projects, or how to change or remove the assignment.
&users; &roles;
Creating or Deleting A Project &project-disable;
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
On the Admin tab, select the Projects category.
To add a new project:
Click Create Project.
In the window that opens, enter a Name and Description for the project.
For details about defining project members or setting quotas for the project, refer to and respectively.
Confirm your changes.
The ‐ automatically assigns an ID and shows the newly created project in the Projects category.
To delete one or multiple projects:
Activate the check boxes in front of the projects that you want to delete.
Click Delete Projects and confirm your choice in the pop-up that appears.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
To temporarily deactivate a project: Click More Edit Project and deactivate the Enabled check box.
&cloud; ‐—List of Projects (Administrator's View)
Creating Users Accounts
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
On the Admin tab, select the Users category.
Click Create User.
In the window that opens, enter a User Name and an Email address for the user.
Set a preliminary Password for the user and confirm it.
Assign the user to a Primary Project by selecting the respective project from the drop-down list.
If you need to create a new project:
Click the plus icon next to Primary Project.
In the window that opens, enter a Name and Description for the project.
For details about defining project members or setting quotas for the project, refer to and respectively.
Select a Role which to assign to the user. By default, the user is automatically assigned a Member role. This is appropriate in most cases.
&role-admin-warn;
Confirm your changes.
The ‐ automatically assigns an ID and shows the newly created user account in the Users category.
Deleting or Temporarily Disabling Users Accounts
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
On the Admin tab, select the Users category.
If you only want to temporarily deactivate a user account: Select the user, and from the More drop-down list, select Disable.
To delete one or more user accounts:
Activate the check boxes in front of the user accounts that you want to delete.
Click Delete Users and confirm your choice in the pop-up that appears.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
&cloud; ‐—List of Users (Administrator's View)
Modifying User Assignments for a Project
When creating new users, you must assign them to a primary project as described in . To assign users to additional projects or to modify and remove assignments or roles, proceed as follows:
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
On the Admin tab, select the Projects category.
Select the project for which to modify user assignments.
Click Modify Users.
The dialog that opens shows two lists of users on its Project Members' tab: All Users and Project Members.
To assign a user to the current project:
Select a user from the All Users list and click the plus icon next to the user.
This moves the user to the Project Members list. By default, the user is automatically assigned a Member role. This is appropriate in most cases.
If you want to change the role with which the user has been added, select a different role from the drop-down list next to the minus icon. &role-admin-warn;
To remove a user from the current project, select the respective user in the Project Members list and click the minus icon next to the user.
This moves the user to the All Users list.
Confirm your changes.

Managing Images &images;
&img-manage;
&img-ownership;
&img-props;
Adding Images
Since the &ostack; Grizzly release, it is possible to upload images also via the ‐. Images can either be uploaded from external URLs or from a local file system. Upload of compressed image binaries (.zip and .tar.gz) is supported.
Limitations for Image Upload via ‐
For upload from an external URL, the image must be available via a valid HTTP URL that leads directly to the image binary. URLs that redirect or serve error pages will result in unusable images.
Avoid upload of large images via ‐. For image sizes of several GB, it is strongly recommended to use the command-line tools. For details, refer to . taroth 2013-07-22: ToDo - point to ID in UG instead (as soon as the CLI chapter contains this contents)
Only a limited set of image properties are accessible from the ‐. It is therefore recommended to set and modify image properties from the command line. For details, refer to .
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
On the Admin tab, select the Images category.
Click Create Image.
In the window that opens, enter a Name for the image.
If you have an external URL to upload the image from, enter the URL into Image Location. For a local image to upload, enter the path into Image File or click Browse.
Select the image Format.
If you want to specify a minimum disk size or minimum RAM size that is required to boot the image, enter the values into the respective input fields. Otherwise the minimums are set to 0.
Confirm your changes.
The image is uploaded to the &ostack; &img; service.
After images have been added, they appear in the &cloud; ‐ on the Admin tab. View them in the Images category.
&cloud; ‐—List of Images (Administrator's View)
From there, you can also Edit some image properties. As only a limited set of image properties are accessible from the ‐, it is preferable to set and modify image properties from the command line. For example, to make sure that an image is only launched on appropriate hypervisors, you can specify image properties that refer to a certain architecture, hypervisor type or application binary interface (ABI) that the image requires. For more details, refer to .
If you need to delete an image, proceed as follows.
Deleting Images
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
On the Admin tab, select the Images category.
To delete one or multiple images, activate the check boxes in front of the images that you want to delete.
Click Delete Images and confirm your choice in the pop-up that appears.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.

&flavors-default;
Via the &cloud; ‐, you can create new flavors, edit or delete existing ones.
Creating, Modifying or Deleting Flavors
On the Admin tab, select the Flavors category.
To create a new flavor or modify an existing one:
Click Create Flavor or select a flavor and click Edit Flavor.
In the window that opens, specify the required parameters for the flavor.
Confirm your changes.
The newly created flavor will appear in the list of flavors and can be used when launching new instances.
To add additional metadata, which custom schedulers can use for appropriately scheduling instances:
Select the flavor to modify and click More View Extra Specs .
In the Flavor Extra Specs view that opens, click Create.
Enter a Key and a Value.
Confirm your changes to create a new key-value pair for a flavor.
Create, modify, or delete extra specs as desired and Close the view to return to the Flavors category.
To delete one or multiple flavors:
Activate the check boxes in front of the flavors that you want to delete.
Click Delete Flavors and confirm your choice in the pop-up that appears.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
&cloud; ‐—List of Flavors (Administrator's View)

Setting Quotas
"as;
&quota-params;
Setting Quotas for a Project
Quotas for a project can also be set when creating the project. To modify them afterwards, proceed as follows:
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
On the Admin tab, select the Projects category.
Select the project for which to set or change quota values.
From the More drop-down list, select Modify Quota.
The window that opens shows the current quota values for the selected project. If no modifications have been made yet, the values reflect the default values per project that are hard-coded in &ostack; ∁.
Change the values for the quota parameters as desired.
Confirm your changes.

procedure.title: Creating or Modifying Subnets
procedure.para: A subnet is a block of IP addresses and other network configuration (for example, a default gateway, DNS servers) that can be associated with an &ostack; &netw; network. Each subnet represents an IPv4 or IPv6 address block. Multiple subnets can be associated with a network, if necessary.
&wip; By default, the first IP address of the specified network address is used as Gateway (for example, if you specified 192.168.0.0/24 as network address, 192168.0.1 is used as gateway).

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
On the Admin tab, select the Networks category.
Select a network and click its Network Name to view the details for the network.
Click Create Subnet or select a subnet and click Edit Subnet.
In the window that opens, enter a name for the subnet or change the existing name.
Enter or change the Network Address. It must be specified in CIDR format, for example:
Choose the IP Version to use (IPv4 or IPv6).
If you want to use another Gateway IP like the default one, enter a Gateway IP. Otherwise, leave the input field blank.
If you do not want to use a gateway, activate Disable Gateway.
To specify additional attributes for the subnet, click the Subnet Detail tab and proceed as follows:
Specify if to Enable DHCP.

procedure.title: Creating or Modifying Ports
procedure.para: A port is an attachment port to a L2 &ostack; &netw; network. When a port is created on the network, it will be associated with a security group. If no security group is specified, it will be associated with a default security group. By default, the port will be allocated an available fixed IP address out of one of the designated subnets for each IP version. When the port is destroyed, the allocated addresses return to the pool of available IPs on the subnet(s). Users of the &ostack; &netw; API can either choose a specific IP address from the block, or let &ostack; &netw; choose the first available IP address.
You can create a port for the network and specify a device ID to be attached to the port.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
On the Admin tab, select the Networks category.
Select a network and click its Network Name to view the details for the network.

procedure.title: Creating or Modifying Routers
procedure.para: &wip;, the following is taken from http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-network/2.0/content/router_ext_concepts.html A router is used to interconnect subnets and forward traffic among them. Another feature of the router is to NAT internal traffic to external networks. A router has an interface for each subnet it is associated with. By default the IP address of such interface is the subnet's gateway IP. Also, whenever a router is associated with a subnet, a port for that router interface will be added to the subnet's network. taroth 2013-08-07: DEVs, is this something that is an admin task at all? or is it rather a user task (as the option "create router" is only available from the project tab, _not_ from the admin tab... - any idea why?

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
On the Project tab, select the Routers category.
Click Create Router.
The window that opens, enter a Router Name and confirm your choice.
The Routers category shows the newly created router.
To connect an external network to the router:
Click Set Gateway for the newly created router.
In the windows that opens, select the External Network which to connect to the router and confirm your choice.
To connect a subnet to the router:
Click the router's name to view the Router Details.
Click Add Interface.
In the window that opens, select the Subnet which to connect to the router and confirm your choice.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.

After having created a new router and having connected it to an external network and a gateway, you can view a graphical representation of the network topology by switching to the Project tab and clicking Network Topology.
